Even here nothing is said as to the duty of the Church to go out into all the world and preach the Gospel to every creature 3 nothing is said as to making proselytes from the Gentiles or even from the unbelieving Jews. It is the exhortation of the Bishop, whose aim is the reformation and improvement of the Chumh, not of the Apostle, whose aim is the extension of the Church by the diffusion of the faith.

In my note I have pointed out that the words of ver. 20, ‘he who recalls an erring brother saves (or ‘ will save ’) his soul from death and will be the means of blotting out many sins’ are capable of two interpretations, according to the reference we give to ‘ his.’ Ι 110νο mentioned some difficulties which lie in the way of our taking ⁶ his' to refer to the sinuer, and have shown that it was not uncommon with Jewish writers to hold forth the prospect of salvation and forgive- ness of sins, as an inducement to certain kinds of right conduct, such as alms-giving. I postponed to the present occasion the consideration of the question whether it was possible that St. James should have adopted a similar mode of speaking. We cannot, of course, imagine that he would ever have dreamt of a man's being able to atone for his own sins by his assiduity in calling others to repentance.
